Diversity of MIMO Multihop Relay Channelsâ€”PartÂ I: Amplify-and-Forward

Sheng Yang and Jean-Claude Belfiore Manuscript submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory. The authors are with the Department of Communications and Electronics, Ã‰cole Nationale SupÃ©rieure des TÃ©lÃ©communications, 46, rue Barrault, 75013 Paris, FranceÂ (e-mail: syang@enst.fr; belfiore@enst.fr).
Abstract

In this two-part paper, we consider the multiantenna multihop relay channels in which the source signal arrives at the destination through Nğ‘N independent relaying hops in series. The main concern of this work is to design relaying strategies that utilize efficiently the relays in such a way that the diversity is maximized. In partÂ I, we focus on the amplify-and-forwardÂ (AF) strategy with which the relays simply scale the received signal and retransmit it. More specifically, we characterize the diversity-multiplexing tradeoffÂ (DMT) of the AF scheme in a general multihop channel with arbitrary number of antennas and arbitrary number of hops. The DMT is in closed-form expression as a function of the number of antennas at each node. First, we provide some basic results on the DMT of the general Rayleigh product channels. It turns out that these results have very simple and intuitive interpretation. Then, the results are applied to the AF multihop channels which is shown to be equivalent to the Rayleigh product channel, in the DMT sense. Finally, the project-and-forwardÂ (PF) scheme, a variant of the AF scheme, is proposed. We show that the PF scheme has the same DMT as the AF scheme, while the PF can have significant power gain over the AF scheme in some cases. In part II, we will derive the upper bound on the diversity of the multihop channels and show that it can be achieved by partitioning the multihop channel into AF subchannels.

Index Terms:
Multihop, multiple-input multiple outputÂ (MIMO), relay channel, amplify-and-forwardÂ (AF), diversity-multiplexing tradeoffÂ (DMT).

I Introduction and Problem Description

Wireless relaying systems have lots of advantages over traditional direct transmission systems. For example, the periphery can be extended by the relays and the coverage of the existing network can be improved. Using relays can also shorten the point to point transmission distance, which results in lower powerÂ (interference) level or in higher throughput. Furthermore, all these benefits can be realized in a more flexible, easier and cheaper to deploy network.

Recently, there has been a boosting interest in the cooperative diversity with which the spatial diversity is exploited through distributed relays. Since the work of Sendonaris et al.â€‰Â [1, 2] that introduced the notion of cooperative diversity, a number of relaying protocols have been proposedÂ (see, e.g., [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10]). Most of the previous works consider the single-antenna two-hop relay channel where the source signal is able to arrive at the destination through at most two hops, i.e., the source-relay hop and relay-destination hop. In an Nğ‘N-relay channel, it is shown that a diversity order of N+1ğ‘1N+1Â (respectively, Nğ‘N) can be achieved withÂ (respectively, without) the direct source-destination link.

In this work, we consider the MIMO multihop channel model without direct source-destination link. That is, the source signal arrives at the destination through Nğ‘N independent relaying hops in series. In the two-hop case, our model is reduced to the model studied by Jing and HassibiÂ [6]. The central concern of our work is to design relaying strategies that utilize efficiently the relays in such a way that the diversity is maximized. In partÂ I, we focus on the amplify-and-forwardÂ (AF) strategy with which the relays simply scale the received signal and retransmit it. The main contributions of this paper are as follows.

  1. 1.

    First, we obtain the diversity-multiplexing tradeoffÂ (DMT) of the Rayleigh product channel, whose channel matrix is a product of independent Gaussian matrices. It turns out that each Rayleigh product channel belongs to an equivalent class that is uniquely represented by the so-called minimal form. Furthermore, based on the closed-form expression of the DMT, we derive a recursive DMT characterization that have very simple and intuitive interpretation.

  2. 2.

    Then, it is shown that the AF multihop channel is actually equivalent to the Rayleigh product channel. We can thus identify the two channels and all previously established results apply to the multihop channel. Therefore, the diversity properties of the AF multihop channel in terms of the number of hops and the number of antennas in each node are completely characterized. We also propose the project-and-forwardÂ (PF) scheme, a variant of the AF scheme, in the case where full antenna cooperation is possible. It is shown that, although the PF scheme has the same DMT as the AF scheme, the PF can have significant power gain over the AF scheme in some cases.

  3. 3.

    Finally, it is pointed out that using less relaying antennas improve the power gain by avoiding the hardening of relayed noise, a particular phenomenon in the AF multihop channel. And reducing the number of transmit antennas can lower significantly the coding delay and decoding complexity. The vertical channel reduction result gives exactly the minimum number of antennas we need at each node to keep the same DMT.

In partÂ II of this paper, we will derive an upper bound on the diversity of the multihop channels and show that the AF scheme is not optimal in general. Then, we will proposed both distributed and non-distributed schemes that achieve the upper bound. The main idea is to partition the multihop channel into AF subchannels.

The rest of partÂ I is organized as follows. SectionÂ II presents the channel model and the AF scheme with some basic assumptions. The Rayleigh product channel is introduced and studied in sectionÂ III. Results concerning the AF and PF schemes are collected in sectionÂ IV. In sectionÂ V, numerical results on some typical scenarios are shown. Finally, we draw a brief conclusion in sectionÂ VI. For fluidity of the presentation, all demonstrations of proofs are delayed to the appendices.

II-C Diversity-Multiplexing Tradeoff

In this paper, we use the diversity-multiplexing tradeoffÂ (DMT) as the performance measure.

Definition 1 (Multiplexing and diversity gains[11])

The multiplexing gain rğ‘Ÿr and diversity gain dğ‘‘d of a fading channel are defined by

râ‰œlimSNRâ†’âˆRâ€‹(ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±)logâ¡ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±anddâ‰œâˆ’limSNRâ†’âˆlogâ¡Poutâ€‹(ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±,R)logâ¡ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±formulae-sequenceâ‰œğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ†’SNRğ‘…ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±andâ‰œğ‘‘subscriptâ†’SNRsubscriptğ‘ƒoutğ–²ğ–­ğ–±ğ‘…ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±r\triangleq\lim_{{\scriptscriptstyle\textsf{SNR}}\to\infty}\frac{R({\mathsf{SNR}})}{\log{\mathsf{SNR}}}\quad\textrm{and}\quad d\triangleq-\lim_{{\scriptscriptstyle\textsf{SNR}}\to\infty}\frac{\log P_{\textrm{out}}({\mathsf{SNR}},R)}{\log{\mathsf{SNR}}}

where Râ€‹(ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±)ğ‘…ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±R({\mathsf{SNR}}) is the target data rate and Poutâ€‹(ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±,R)subscriptğ‘ƒoutğ–²ğ–­ğ–±ğ‘…P_{\textrm{out}}({\mathsf{SNR}},R) is the outage probability for a target rate Rğ‘…R. A more compact form is

Poutâ€‹(ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±,râ€‹logâ¡ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±)â‰ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±âˆ’d.approaches-limitsubscriptğ‘ƒoutğ–²ğ–­ğ–±ğ‘Ÿğ–²ğ–­ğ–±superscriptğ–²ğ–­ğ–±ğ‘‘P_{\textrm{out}}({\mathsf{SNR}},r\log{\mathsf{SNR}})\doteq{\mathsf{SNR}}^{-d}. (3)

Note that in the definition we use the outage probability instead of the error probability, since it is shown in [11] that the error probability is dominated by the outage probability in the high SNR regime and that the thus defined DMT is the best that we can achieve with any coding scheme.

III The Rayleigh Product Channel

As it is shown in the next section, the AF multihop channels are intimately related to a more general Rayleigh product channel defined below. In this section, we investigate the Rayleigh product channel and provides some basic results on the diversity. Let us begin by the following definitions.

For example, a (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2) channel is equivalent to a (1,2,3,4)1234(1,2,3,4) channel, in the eigen-exponent sense.

Theorem 2

A (n0,n1,â€¦,nN)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel can be reduced to a (n~0,n~1,â€¦,n~k)subscript~ğ‘›0subscript~ğ‘›1â€¦subscript~ğ‘›ğ‘˜(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{k}) channel if and only if

kâ€‹(n~k+1+1)â‰¥âˆ‘l=0kn~l.ğ‘˜subscript~ğ‘›ğ‘˜11superscriptsubscriptğ‘™0ğ‘˜subscript~ğ‘›ğ‘™k(\tilde{n}_{k+1}+1)\geq\sum_{l=0}^{k}\tilde{n}_{l}. (8)

In particular, it can be reduced to a Rayleigh channel if and only if

n~2+1â‰¥n~0+n~1.subscript~ğ‘›21subscript~ğ‘›0subscript~ğ‘›1\tilde{n}_{2}+1\geq\tilde{n}_{0}+\tilde{n}_{1}. (9)

This theorem implies that (n~0,n~1,â€¦,n~Nâˆ—)subscript~ğ‘›0subscript~ğ‘›1â€¦subscript~ğ‘›superscriptğ‘(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{N^{*}}) is a minimal form if there exists no k<Nâˆ—ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘k<N^{*} such that (8) is satisfied. One can also verify that if (n~0,n~1,â€¦,n~Nâˆ—)subscript~ğ‘›0subscript~ğ‘›1â€¦subscript~ğ‘›superscriptğ‘(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{N^{*}}) is a minimal horizontal form of (n0,n1,â€¦,nN)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}), then 1)Â it is also a minimal form; and 2)Â the minimal vertical form is (n~0,n~1,â€¦,n~Nâˆ—,nÂ¯,â€¦,nÂ¯)subscript~ğ‘›0subscript~ğ‘›1â€¦subscript~ğ‘›superscriptğ‘Â¯ğ‘›â€¦Â¯ğ‘›(\tilde{n}_{0},\tilde{n}_{1},\ldots,\tilde{n}_{N^{*}},\bar{n},\ldots,\bar{n}) where

Furthermore, note that the order Nâˆ—superscriptğ‘N^{*} is upper-bounded by n~0subscript~ğ‘›0\tilde{n}_{0} because (8) is always satisfied with k=n~0ğ‘˜subscript~ğ‘›0k=\tilde{n}_{0}. In other words, the length of the minimal form is bounded by n~0+1subscript~ğ‘›01\tilde{n}_{0}+1. In particular, the minimal form of a (1,n1,â€¦,nN)1subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(1,n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel is always (1,n1)1subscriptğ‘›1(1,n_{1}), i.e., a 1Ã—n~11subscript~ğ‘›11\times\tilde{n}_{1} or n~1Ã—1subscript~ğ‘›11\tilde{n}_{1}\times 1 Rayleigh channel.

Theorem 3

Two Rayleigh product channels are equivalent if and only if they have the same minimal form.

From this theorem, we deduce that the class of exponential equivalence is uniquely identified by the minimal form. Therefore, Nâˆ—superscriptğ‘N^{*} can also be defined as the order of the class.

III-B Characterization of the Diversity-Multiplexing Tradeoff

From theoremÂ 1, we can derive the DMT of a Rayleigh product channel.

Theorem 4 (Direct characterization)

The DMT of a Rayleigh product channelÂ (n0,n1,â€¦,nN)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) is a piecewise-linear function connecting the pointsÂ (k,dâ€‹(k))ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘˜(k,d(k)), k=0,1,â€¦,nminğ‘˜01â€¦subscriptğ‘›k=0,1,\ldots,n_{\min}, where

dâ€‹(k)=âˆ‘i=k+1nminciğ‘‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–d(k)=\sum_{i=k+1}^{n_{\min}}c_{i} (11)

with cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} defined by (7).

Since the DMT is a bijection of the coefficients cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i}â€™s, all results obtained previously apply to the DMT and two Rayleigh product channels are equivalent if and only if they have the same DMT. Hence, the exponential equivalence class is also the DMT-equivalence class. However, unlike the eigen-exponent, the DMT provides an insight on the diversity performance of a channelÂ (or a scheme) for different multiplexing gain. Note that, despite the closed-form nature of the characterization (11), it is lack of intuition. That is why we search for an alternative characterization.

Theorem 5 (Recursive characterization)

The DMT dâ€‹(k)ğ‘‘ğ‘˜d(k) defined in (11) can be alternatively characterized by

R1(N)(k):d(n0,â€¦,nN)(k)\displaystyle R_{1}^{(N)}(k)~{}:\quad d_{(n_{0},\ldots,n_{N})}(k) =d(n0âˆ’k,â€¦,nNâˆ’k)â€‹(0),âˆ€k;absentsubscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ‘›0ğ‘˜â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘˜0for-allğ‘˜\displaystyle=d_{(n_{0}-k,\ldots,n_{N}-k)}(0),\quad\forall k; (12)

(14)

The recursive characterization has an intuitive interpretation as follows. Let us consider kğ‘˜k as a â€œnetwork flowâ€ between the source and the destination and dâ€‹(k)ğ‘‘ğ‘˜d(k) as the minimum â€œcostâ€ to limit the flow to kğ‘˜kÂ (the flow-kğ‘˜k event). In particular, the maximum diversity dâ€‹(0)ğ‘‘0d(0) can be seen as the â€œdisconnection costâ€. First, R1â€‹(k)subscriptğ‘…1ğ‘˜R_{1}(k) says that the most efficient way to limit the flow to kğ‘˜k is to keep a (k,k,â€¦,k)ğ‘˜ğ‘˜â€¦ğ‘˜(k,k,\ldots,k) channel fully connected and to disconnect the (n0âˆ’k,n1âˆ’k,â€¦,nNâˆ’k)subscriptğ‘›0ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›1ğ‘˜â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘˜(n_{0}-k,n_{1}-k,\ldots,n_{N}-k) residual channel, as shown in Fig.Â â€‹3(a). Then, R2â€‹(i)subscriptğ‘…2ğ‘–R_{2}(i) suggests that in order to disconnect a (n0,n1,â€¦,nN)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) channel, if we allow for jğ‘—j flows from the source to some node iğ‘–i, then the (j,ni+1,â€¦,nN)ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(j,n_{i+1},\ldots,n_{N}) channel from the jğ‘—j â€œendsâ€ of the flows at nodeÂ iğ‘–i to the destination must be disconnected. The idea is shown in Fig.Â â€‹3(b). Obviously, the most efficient way is such that the total cost is minimized with respect to jğ‘—j. This interpretation sheds lights on the typical outage event of the Rayleigh product channel. In the trivial case of N=1ğ‘1N=1 (the Rayleigh channel), there is only one subchannel. The typical and only way for the channel to be in outage is that all the paths are bad, i.e., the disconnection cost is n~0Ã—n~1subscript~ğ‘›0subscript~ğ‘›1\tilde{n}_{0}\times\tilde{n}_{1}. In the non-trivial cases, there are more than one subchannels and thus the typical outage event is not necessarily for one of the subchannels being totally bad. The mismatch of two partially bad subchannels can also cause outage. In a more general way, the flow-kğ‘˜k event takes place when both the flow-jğ‘—j event in the (n0,â€¦,ni)subscriptğ‘›0â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–(n_{0},\ldots,n_{i}) channel and the flow-kğ‘˜k event in the (j,ni+1,â€¦,nk)ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜(j,n_{i+1},\ldots,n_{k}) channel happen at the same time. We can verify that (R1â€‹(k),R3â€‹(i,k))subscriptğ‘…1ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…3ğ‘–ğ‘˜(R_{1}(k),R_{3}(i,k)) is equivalent to (R1â€‹(k),R2â€‹(i))subscriptğ‘…1ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘…2ğ‘–(R_{1}(k),R_{2}(i)). Note that the DMT is completely characterized by these relations in a recursive manner.

In the rest of the paper, we identify the Rayleigh product channel, the AF multihop channel and the vector (n0,n1,â€¦,nN)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) when confusion is not likely.

IV-B A VariantÂ : Project-and-Forward

We propose a new scheme called project-and-forwardÂ (PF), as shown in Fig.Â â€‹5. This scheme can be used only when full antenna cooperation within cluster is possible, that is, all antennas in the same cluster are controlled by a central unit. At the nodeÂ #iğ‘–i, the received signal is first projected to the signal subspace ğ’®isubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i}, spanned by the columns of the channel matrix ğ‘¯Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯ğ‘–\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i}. The dimension of ğ’®isubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i} is risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}, the rank of ğ‘¯Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯ğ‘–\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i}. After the component-wise normalization, the projected signal is transmitted using risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}Â (out of nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}) antennas. It is now clear that ğ‘¯Â¯i+1âˆˆâ„‚ni+1Ã—risubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯ğ‘–1superscriptâ„‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i+1}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i+1}\times r_{i}} is actually composed of the risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} columns of the previously defined ğ‘¯i+1subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘–1{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i+1}, with r0â‰œn0â‰œsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0subscriptğ‘›0r_{0}\triangleq n_{0}.

More precisely, the ğ‘¸Â¯iâˆˆâ„‚niÃ—risubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸ğ‘–superscriptâ„‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{n_{i}\times r_{i}} is an orthogonal basis of ğ’®isubscriptğ’®ğ‘–\mathcal{S}_{i} with ğ‘¸Â¯iâ€ â€‹ğ‘¸Â¯i=ğˆsubscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸â€ ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸ğ‘–ğˆ{\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}_{i}\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i}=\mathbf{I}. We can rewrite

ğ‘¯Â¯i=ğ‘¸Â¯iâ€‹ğ‘®Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğ‘®ğ‘–\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i}=\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i}\underline{{\boldsymbol{G}}}_{i}

with ğ‘®Â¯iâˆˆâ„‚riÃ—riâˆ’1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘®ğ‘–superscriptâ„‚subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1\underline{{\boldsymbol{G}}}_{i}\in\mathbb{C}^{r_{i}\times r_{i-1}}. For simplicity, we let ğ‘¸Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸ğ‘–\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}_{i} be obtained by the QR decomposition of ğ‘¯Â¯isubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯ğ‘–\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{i} if ni>riâˆ’1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1n_{i}>r_{i-1} and be identity matrix if niâ‰¤risubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–n_{i}\leq r_{i}. The main idea of the PF scheme is not to use more antennas than necessary to forward the signal. Since the useful signal lies only in the risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}-dimensional signal subspace, the projection of the received signal provides sufficient statistics and reduces the noise power by a factor nirisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–\frac{n_{i}}{r_{i}}. In this case, only risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} antennas are needed to forward the projected signal. Let us define ğ‘·iâ‰œğ‘«Â¯iâ€‹ğ‘¸Â¯iâ€ â‰œsubscriptğ‘·ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğ‘«ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¸â€ ğ‘–{\boldsymbol{P}}_{i}\triangleq\underline{{\boldsymbol{D}}}_{i}{\underline{{\boldsymbol{Q}}}}^{\scriptscriptstyle{\dagger}\!}_{i}. Then, as in the AF case, the PF multihop channel is DMT-equivalent to the channel defined by

ğš·PF=ğ‘¯Â¯Nâ€‹ğ‘·Nâˆ’1â€‹â‹¯â€‹ğ‘¯Â¯2â€‹ğ‘·1â€‹ğ‘¯Â¯1.subscriptğš·PFsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘·ğ‘1â‹¯subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯2subscriptğ‘·1subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¯1{\boldsymbol{\Pi}}_{\text{PF}}=\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{N}{\boldsymbol{P}}_{N-1}\cdots\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{2}{\boldsymbol{P}}_{1}\underline{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{1}.

The following theorem states that using only risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} out of nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} antennas to forward the projected signal does not incur any loss of diversity, as compared to the AF scheme.

Theorem 7

The PF multihop channel is DMT-equivalent to a (n0,n1,â€¦,nN)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}) Rayleigh product channel.

While the PF and AF have the same diversity gain, the PF outperforms the AF in power gain for two reasons. One reason is, as stated before, that the projection reduces the average noise power. The other reason is that the accumulated noise in the AF case is more substantial than that in the PF case. This is because in the PF case, less relay antennas are used than in the AF case. Since the power of independent noises from different transmit antennas add up at the receiver side, the accumulated noise in the AF case â€œenjoysâ€ a larger â€œtransmit diversity orderâ€ than in the PF case. We call it the noise hardening effect. Some examples will be given in the section of numerical results.

IV-C Practical Issues

IV-C1 Space-Time Coding

From the input-output point of view, the multihop channel with AF/PF protocol is merely a linear MIMO fading channel, for which the DMT-achieving space-time codes exist. For example, in [11], a Gaussian code is shown to achieve the DMT of a n0Ã—n1subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1n_{0}\times n_{1} Rayleigh channel if the code length lâ‰¥n0+n1âˆ’1ğ‘™subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›11l\geq n_{0}+n_{1}-1. This result can easily be extended to a general linear fading channel and one can show that Gaussian coding is DMT-achieving for any fading statistics if lğ‘™l is large enough.

Another family of code construction is based on cyclic division algebraÂ (CDA). These codes have minimum lengthÂ n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} and are commonly known as the Perfect codesÂ [12, 13]. They are DMT-achieving thanks to the so-called non-vanishing determinantÂ (NVD) property. It has been shown that they are approximately universalÂ [14, 13] since they are DMT-achieving for all fading statistics. Therefore, we propose to use the rate-n~0subscript~ğ‘›0\tilde{n}_{0} n0Ã—n0subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0}\times n_{0} Perfect codes. In this case, the only information that the source need to know is n~0subscript~ğ‘›0\tilde{n}_{0}.

IV-C2 Antenna Reduction

In the AF case, provided the number of total available antennas (n0,n1,â€¦,nN)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘(n_{0},n_{1},\ldots,n_{N}), the vertical reduction result gives an exact number of necessary antennas at each node in the DMT sense. This result can be used to reduce the number of transmit and relay antennas444Reducing the number of receive antennas does not do any good, since more receive antennas always provide larger power gain without increasing the complexity.. If Perfect space-time codes are used, reducing the number of transmit antennas n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} means reducing the coding length, i.e., coding delay and decoding complexity, since the code length is equal to the number of transmit antennas. For instance, only two transmit antennas are needed in a (4,2,2,2)4222(4,2,2,2) channel. Therefore, instead of using a 4Ã—4444\times 4 Perfect code the code length of which is 444, one can use the Golden codeÂ [15] of length 222 and still achieve the DMT.

In fact, less relay antennas also means less relay signalingÂ (relay probing, synchronization, etc.) overhead especially when different antennas are from different relaying terminalsÂ (single-antenna relays). Furthermore, using more relay antennas hardens the relayed noise. This is the same phenomenon as we stated in the PF case. Therefore, the number of relay antennas at each node should be restricted to nÂ¯Â¯ğ‘›\bar{n} (defined in (10)), the number given by the vertical reduction.

V Examples and Numerical Results

In this section, we provide some examples of multihop channels and show the performance of AF scheme with simulation results. In all cases, we make the same assumptions as in sectionÂ II.

V-A Horizontal and Vertical Reduction

Outage performances versus the received SNR per node of different multihop channels are shown in Fig.Â â€‹7. Note that both the (2,2)22(2,2) and (2,2,2)222(2,2,2) channels are minimal and have diversity order 444 and 333, respectively. The (3,2,2)322(3,2,2) channel can be horizontally reduced to (2,2)22(2,2) and thus has diversity 444. Similarly, the (2,2,2,2)2222(2,2,2,2), (4,2,2,2)4222(4,2,2,2) and (8,2,2,2)8222(8,2,2,2) channels can be reduced to (2,2,2)222(2,2,2) and have diversity 333. As compared to the (2,2,2,2)2222(2,2,2,2) channel, the larger number of transmit antennas in the (8,2,2,2)8222(8,2,2,2) weakens the fading of the first hop and the performance is close to the (2,2,2)222(2,2,2) channel.

Another example is to illustrate the vertical reduction of multihop channels, as shown in Fig.Â â€‹8. We first consider the case of a (1,4,1)141(1,4,1) channel. The necessary antenna number nÂ¯Â¯ğ‘›\bar{n} is 111 and the minimal vertical form is thus (1,1,1)111(1,1,1). We observe that, although both the (1,4,1)141(1,4,1) and (1,1,1)111(1,1,1) channels have diversity 111, a power gain of 777Â dB is obtained at Pout=10âˆ’4subscriptğ‘ƒoutsuperscript104P_{\text{out}}=10^{-4} by using only one relay antennas out of four, if the AF scheme is used. As stated in sectionÂ IV-C2, the gain is due to avoiding the hardening of relayed noise. Then, we consider the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2) channel. The necessary number of antennas nÂ¯Â¯ğ‘›\bar{n} is 222 in this case. As shown in Fig.Â â€‹8, by restricting the number of relay antennas to 222, we have a (3,1,2,2)3122(3,1,2,2) channel and a gain of 222 dB is observered at Pout=10âˆ’4subscriptğ‘ƒoutsuperscript104P_{\text{out}}=10^{-4}. We can further reduce the number of transmit antennas to 222 to get a (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channel. Unlike the reduction of relay antennas, the reduction of transmit antennas does not provide any gain because it does not affect the relayed noise. In contrast, it degrades the performance since the first hop (2,1)21(2,1) is faded more seriously than the original first hop (3,1)31(3,1). Nevertheless, the (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channel is still better than the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2) channel and is only 0.70.70.7 dB from the (3,1,2,2)3122(3,1,2,2) channel.

V-B Project-and-Forward

In Fig.Â â€‹9, we compare the PF scheme with the AF scheme for the (1,2,1)121(1,2,1) and (1,3,2)132(1,3,2), respectively. First of all, note that the AF and the PF have the same diversity order, as predicted. Then, a power gain of 8.58.58.5Â dBÂ (respectively, 6.56.56.5Â dB) over the AF scheme is obtained by the PF scheme in the (1,2,1)121(1,2,1)Â (respective, (1,3,2)132(1,3,2) channel). This is due to the maximum ratio combiningÂ (MRC) gain in the first hop and to avoiding the relayed noise hardening.

V-C Coded Performance

We now study the coded performance of the AF multihop channel. The performance measure is the symbol error rateÂ (SER) versus the received SNR under the maximum likelihoodÂ (ML) decoding. We still take the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2) channel as an example. Since n~0=1subscript~ğ‘›01\tilde{n}_{0}=1, the diagonal algebraic space-timeÂ (DAST) code555Note that the DAST code is the diagonal version of the rate-one Perfect code proposed in [12].Â [16] can be used. As shown in Fig.Â â€‹10, with the DAST code, the symbol error rate performances of in the (3,1,4,2)3142(3,1,4,2), (3,1,2,2)3122(3,1,2,2) and (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channels have exactly the same behavior as the outage performances of the channels doÂ Fig.Â â€‹8. Moreover, we can use the Alamouti codeÂ [17] for the (2,1,2,2)2122(2,1,2,2) channel. As we can see in the figure, the Alamouti code outperforms all the DAST codes with minimum delay and minimum decoding complexity. The potential benefits from the vertical reduction are thus highlighted.

V-D Multihop vs. Direct Transmission

Finally, we introduce the path loss modelÂ [18]

ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±receivedâˆdistanceâˆ’Î±â€‹ğ–²ğ–­ğ–±transmittedproportional-tosubscriptğ–²ğ–­ğ–±receivedsuperscriptdistanceğ›¼subscriptğ–²ğ–­ğ–±transmitted{\mathsf{SNR}}_{\text{received}}\propto\text{distance}^{-\alpha}{\mathsf{SNR}}_{\text{transmitted}}

where Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the path loss factor. We fix the distance from the source to the destination and dispose the relay nodes on the source-destination line with equal distance. Each node contains two antennas. We compare the 222-, 333- and 444-hop channel with the direct transmissionÂ (single-hop) channel. the performance measure is the transmitted power gain of the multihop channel over the single-hop channel at certain target outage probabilityÂ (10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} and 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}). The path loss factor Î±ğ›¼\alpha takes the typical valuesÂ [18] 333, 3.53.53.5, and 444 for wireless channels. In Fig.Â â€‹11(a), the total transmission power in the multihop channel is considered. Power gain is obtained for Î±=3.5ğ›¼3.5\alpha=3.5 and 444. Then, the transmission power per node is considered in Fig.Â â€‹11(b). In this case, power gain is obtained for all Î±ğ›¼\alpha and is as high as 111111Â dB. In practice, the transmission power per node also represents the interference level for other terminals which has a significant impact on the network capacity. In both figures, the power gain is lower at 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4} than at 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3}. This is due to the fact that the direct transmission channel is a 2Ã—2222\times 2 Rayleigh channel and has diversity 444, while the multihop channel is (2,2,â€¦,2)22â€¦2(2,2,\ldots,2) and has diversity 333. And low diversity gain means decreasing power gain with increasing SNR or equivalently, with decreasing outage probability.

VI Conclusion

Perhaps the simplest relaying scheme in the MIMO multihop channel is the Amplify-and-Forward scheme. In part I of this paper, by identifying the AF multihop channel with the so-called Rayleigh product channel, we have obtained the complete characterization of the diversity-multiplexing tradeoff of the AF scheme in a multihop channel with arbitrary number of antennas and hops. The characterization is provided both in direct closed-form and recursive form. Based on the DMT, a number of properties of the AF multihop channel have been derived.

In the second part, we will show that the AF scheme is suboptimal in general, by establishing the diversity upper bound of the multihop channel with any relaying scheme. By partitioning the multihop channel into AF subchannels, we achieve the upper bound with both distributed and non-distributed schemes.
